node.title: Australia releases its judges’ reasoning for approving Novak Djokovic’s expulsion.
node.alt: Novak Djokovic (center) after landing at Nikola Tesla Airport in Belgrade, on Jan. 17.
node.description: The decision by the court to uphold the decision of the country’s immigration minister to revoke the tennis star’s visa ended his bid for a 21st Grand Slam trophy.
node.content: ["In ruling in favor of the Australian government\u2019s decision to revoke the visa of Novak Djokovic, the panel of three judges who oversaw the case reasserted the broad authority of the country\u2019s immigration minister and found that he had acted in a way that was both reasonable and rational, according to the ruling released on Thursday.", "The court\u2019s decision, which extinguished Mr. Djokovic\u2019s chance of winning a record 21st men\u2019s Grand Slam title in Melbourne this year, concluded a volatile saga that prompted debate over immigration law, celebrity entitlement and vaccinations.", "The ruling, released by the Federal Court of Australia, was the first public statement of the court\u2019s reasoning.", "\u201cAn iconic world tennis star may influence people of all ages, young or old, but perhaps especially the young and the impressionable, to emulate him,\u201d the panel of three judges found. \u201cThis is not fanciful; it does not need evidence.\u201d", "The court noted the broad authority of the immigration minister, Alex Hawke, to control entry into the country and found he was well within his rights to cancel Mr. Djokovic\u2019s visa on the grounds of \u201chealth and good order.\u201d", "The legal question, the judges said, was not whether Mr. Djokovic actually posed a risk to health, safety and good order to the country, but whether Mr. Hawke was \u201csatisfied\u201d that his presence in the country might amount to one.", "Once held up as an example of how nations could keep Covid cases low, Australia is now tackling its most severe surge since the pandemic began.", "Ultimately, Mr. Hawke\u2019s reasons for revoking the visa \u2014 in part, that Mr. Djokovic\u2019s position as a sporting role model who chose to remain unvaccinated against Covid-19 could \u201cfoster anti-vaccination sentiment\u201d \u2014 were not \u201cirrational or illogical or not based on relevant material,\u201d the three judges said.", "Though Mr. Hawke did not have to provide his reasons for canceling Mr. Djokovic\u2019s visa, the judgment said they were \u201ccarefully drafted,\u201d and showed that he had exercised the discretionary power lawfully.", "\u201cAnother person in the position of the minister may have not canceled Mr. Djokovic\u2019s visa,\u201d the judges wrote. \u201cThe minister did.\u201d"]
